From the moment first moment I stepped into the plush hotel lobby (3am!) the staff have always gone out of their way to look after me and my colleagues. I've stayed on every floor of the Hyatt and seen it through a refurb too. To be honest interior decoration is obviously lost on me because I hardly noticed the difference. However all the rooms were clean, tidy and very comfortable. I love the bathrooms although the shower drainage can be a little slow. No free internet either which for me is a disappointment at any hotel, whatever the star rating. The food at the Hyatt is excellent. For the first few trips I was overindulging at breakfast but soon found out this wasn't a great…

The Hyatt is a decent hotel, but for what's supposed to be the best hotel in town, I wasn't particularly impressed (I also tried Le Doge, which isn't necessarily better.) The rooms are fine and the breakfast spread is pretty good (although there were flies around the uncovered items every time I stayed and ate there over several weeks). The staff isn't very competent, however, and the concierge was pretty much useless for recommendations and information on places around town. They even have an outdoor pool, which isn't huge but big enough to do a few laps when it's warm enough. All in all, I would probably stay here again since there isn't anything better.

The central location was awesome and allowed for some fantastic sights and some rather "interesting" sights. The restaurants in the hotel were beautiful with the most wonderful staff and the most delicious food. Bed was comfy and room was very clean! Kudos to the staff...you could see that they truly enjoyed doing what they do!

column3: Non tutto cio' che luccica e' oro
column4: This hotel is in a central location, although don't let the name full you. The standards of the room are quite low for a 5 star luxury hotel. It's not very cleaned and it's not rare to see flyers arround the food at breakfast. The service is good and helpful. Stop here if you are travelling or business, avoid it if you are hoping in a romantic little place.

I stayed at the Hyatt in Casablanca after coming off of a 21 day trip around Morocco staying in a wide range of accommodation, some great others not so much. This Hyatt offers quiet upscale accommodation, extremely friendly staff, wonderfully comfortable beds and an amazing French restaurant in the hotel. The Regency Club is better then most offered by Hyatt, very nice wine and canapés, you could actually make a full meal if so inclined. The location couldn't be better, on the edge of the medina, my suite has a beautiful view of the Grand Mosque and the harbor. All in all if what you want is consistency, great service, wonderful food and location, this is the right place for you.

What a great place to stay in Casablanca. After a terrible experience at the Sofitel, Essaouria we made our way to Casablanca. The Hyatt Regency Casablanca provided everything we wanted. Great comfort, great food, good location, excellent service.

If you're looking for something Moroccan, this hotel isn't it. It has some classic features (like the area for breakfast) but for the most part is Westernised. The restaurant was quite good, but the food is Western. One curiosity was the toilet in the room - for a large room, one had to squeeze into the toilet room which was probably smaller than a domestic one!!

column3: Very well-located hotel, close to the medina!
column4: My partner and I stayed here for one night upon our arrival in Morocco. A great place to recover from your airplane trip before moving on to explore the rest of the country. Rooms are spacious, with superb beds, clean and quiet. We did not try any of the restaurants or the gym or pool, so I can't comment on those amenities. The price of the hotel is high, about what you'd pay for a hotel in New York City, and well above what hotels outside of Casablanca cost, but it is a very comfortable stopover, with a superb location just a block from the entrance to the medina.

column3: Great Hotel, good located, friendly staff
column4: I stayed in this hotel for one night as part of a business trip, and was really very well impressed. Great room, clean, and comfortable. I do not give the hotel an excellent classification, because of two things: first is that there is no ironing in the room (something key for business travellers), and the day I was about to leave, I booked a car to the airport for 10:30PM, I was at the lobby at 10:30, the concierge called a driver, a guy came and had a very hard discussion with the concierge (I was not able to understand a single word but assumed was the driver), which somehow made me feel not comfortable. The SIxPM bar is great. Super ambiance, great athosphere, not cheap, but totally aligned to prices you pay in similar bars, in same hotel level. No complains at all. The…

column3: Business hotel, but great for tourists too
column4: Casablanca city was "an experience", and we were glad to be staying in a really comfortable hotel with a great pool, an oasis in the big bad city. Rooms were great, spacious, brilliant shower, comforatble beds, modern decoration. Bar areas were great, drinks not too cheap, but not unexpected for the size & style of hotel and espcially as it is a muslim country where alcohol is obviously not viewed in the same way as the UK. We had breakfast each day in the hotel and it was really nice. We also ate in one of the hotel restaurants which was terrific food, and while it was the most expensive meal we had while we were in Morocco, we didn't feel it was over-priced. The staff were all very sweet and attentive - the guys in the bar remembered exactly what we liked to drink, having had…

column3: Comfortable and what you would expect.......
column4: After a long transatlantic flight the Hyatt was clean, comfortable and what you would expect. No surprises here, just all the comforts of home in the center of Casablanca. We were a bit disappointed by our view of the roof but we were too tired to care for one night. Makes for a great launch point to explore the rest of Morocco.

column3: Hard to relax at the Hyatt Regency Casablanca
column4: After choosing to "rough it" at a kite surfing camp, I was really looking fwd to a night in a nice western hotel.  I'd say the Hyatt  in Casablanca came up a bit short.  We made the mistake of grabbing drinks at the hotel discoteque, BlackHouse.  The bar tender picked up on the fact that we were two Americans who don't speak Arabic nor French.  1 Heineken & 1 vodka oj were €11.50 each!  To make matters worse, the bartender didn't bring our change back so the drinks endedup being €13 or $19 each!  I have a really hard time believing the 20 something locals were paying that much.  I wish we would have asked for the price prior to ordering. Tarik, the manager was quite difficult. He wouldn't comp our Internet or breakfast even though the online reservation said those things were…

Have stayed here couple times in past 6 months on business. Overall very good place. Rooms are great, location central and I would definitely stay here again. Reception at airport -- had booked car-pick up on arrival at Casablanca airport but on both occasions the drivers were not waiting in the right place with their placards as everyone else was. I had to call the hotel who had to call them to find me. Check-in -- Very good and efficient. First impressions -- Very nice lobby. Tasteful. Nice bar as well. Rooms -- I had an executive floor room on both times. Very nice views of the grand mosque and the sea. Spacious rooms with comfortable bed and excellent shower. With Nespresso coffee machine and free capsules. Nice and big work desk and plenty of storage space. Executive…

I visited the Hyatt 2 times in April and May of this year as a middle class Australian . I found the room to be very pokey and small. The service sub standard - we were ignored for 15 minutes in the lobby lounge bar area and one of the attendants even had the audacity to ask us if we were guest because he was hesitant to serve us! Every time house keeping came in they didn't knock and just threw open the door so help you if you were getting dressed or something. The gym is pointless and there are always staff in attendance which is nice but people staring at you while you are trying to work out is really awkward. The hotel was clean, location average but the restaurants served great food which was a big plus. But overall I don't recommend you stay here unless you have too.

column3: Excellent hotel in an excellent location
column4: We stayed at the Hyatt Regency the night of June 16th and were very pleased overall with that hotel. True international standards and very professionnal service. Very good restaurants where we had the best oysters in Morocco! The location on the edge of the Medina was very convenient.

column3: Central hotel with great services and staff
column4: Enjoyed the location, the friendness of the staff, and the cleaniness of the entire place. I particularily want to thank the concerige for attempting to locate my bag that was lost by Easyjet somewhere in either Madrid or Casablanca. (Easyjet had it they just could never figure how to get it to me (or where I could retrive it - never did get the bag after trying for 7 days before returning to the States). I do recommend that if you are visiting Casablanca that you visit the new mosque. Very interesting tour of a beautiful site of worship. If you want to say, I ate (or drank) at Ricks by all means go. Just remember there really wasn't a Rick's so you'll be visiting a reality that was really an illusion. (The food was good though:)).

We arrived in Casablanca from the US at sunset and went straight to the Hyatt Regency (http://casablanca.regency.hyatt.com/hyatt/hotels/index.jsp?null). We chose the hotel as a stop over to get us onto Moroccan time prior to headin out to Fes and Marrakech. The hotel was perfect. Four quick points: • The hotel appears plain on the outside, but it is incredible inside with dark hardwood features throughout. The highlight is a large Moorish dorm - carved with gold leaf. The rooms are solid - perfect bathroom for the recovering red-eye flier and solid views of the medina & Hussain II mosque. • The staff was everything that you would expect - friendly, knowledgeable, and dedicated to making your stay successful. • The location is truly convenient - in downtown Casablanca, right…

column3: Great Hotel for business and pleasure....excellent service!
column4: If you are ever in Casa on business or pleasure, make sure you stay at the Hyatt. Central, friendly, clean, loaded with techi stuff in the rooms and the food is just excellent! The rooms 7th upwards are amazing and especially that renovation is almost done. Shame that internet is paiable and this needs to be looked at, especially that the other hotels of this class offer it for free. The value (price to service) is spot on. Try the lobby bar for some great drinks, snaks and even breakfast on the go. The Louise Vuitton shop in the lobby will certainly keep the ladies happy. Comfortable beds, massive showers - all in all an excellent hotel run by some really nice staff.

column3: Comfortable, easy, welcoming – center of town!
column4: The Hyatt regency is bang in the middle of everything in Casablanca. The Corniche, the old parts of town, the places to see are all minutes away. The hotel is old world warmth and charm mixed with all the amenities you might want. The Executive Room had free access to WiFi, a welcome drink at 6pm the bar (one drink, not open bar, remember). Room service is good, food was standard. Overall, good experience. Staff are very friendly and warm. Concierge is very helpful. But I did have one problem. Going back to the airport, the hotel did not have any limos available, so they arranged a taxi (cheaper) but that was one smelly, non A/C long ride. There are some really nice authentic places to eat around the neighborhood, and I had a wonderful tagine dinner just a minute away at an…

column3: We were shunted to another hotel
column4: We were a party of 8 very seasoned travellers who arrived at 8.pm after a 10 hour flight. The purpose of our trip was the celebration of one of our parties' birthday. The plan was to stay just one night before moving on to Marrakech. Our first impression was poor, in that the driveway was blocked - not by neatly uniformed doormen, but by hefty thugs in black suits, so we had to walk up from the road. Despite booking and prepaying for 4 rooms, we were greeted with the news that we were being sent to another hotel of an 'equal standard', as they were completely full, and 'guests were refusing to leave'. The receptionist who imparted this news did with a huge smile, with the expectation we'd be thrilled. We weren't. Turns out that some Saudi royal was there with his…

The Hyatt in Casablanca has everything you'd expect in a big city business hotel. The lobby is plush and large, and is a good place to meet people. The lobby is slightly gaudy, in an upscale Arab way, but that's part of its attraction. My room was comfortable, if a bit modernly non-descript. The towels were thick. The hot water came on instantly. The building itself is a rather unattractive 12-storey white concrete block on a busy square, right outside the medina and near the port. The immediate neighborhood was once the center of Casablanca, but it's now a bit shabby. It's perfectly safe to wander around, and it's full of restaurants and shops. But the business HQs and better restaurants have moved about a kilometer away to the neighborhood around the Twin Towers. If that's…

This is a recently renovated modern luxury hotel in a central location. Decent size room, very comfortable bed and chairs, large desk, excellent lighting, silent HVAC. Expensive internet and no wi-fi in the room (cable only). No tea/coffee equipment, but an electric kettle was promptly delivered upon request. Light sleepers might be bothered by traffic noise in the rooms facing the square (Moroccan drivers beep the horn a lot); rooms facing the opposite way are probably quieter. No problem checking in or out, and there is a bank ATM next to the reception desk.

column3: Stay here- even if you go broke!
column4: I have only one negative thing to say-everything about this hotel is expensive. REALLY expensive. But in my experience, if you want to have American style luxury in Africa, you will have to pay for it. Casablanca is a rough city, and if at all possible, I would avoid it. I happened to fly through there, so I ended up staying a night. But given how grimy and rough that city is, I at least wanted to feel comfortable and happy. The bed- top notch. I slept like a baby. The food? Absolutely amazing. I recommend the moroccon restaurant. Get one of the Pastilles, and a tanginess. You will run up quite a bill- I spent $60 on dinner (I just drank water) and $30 on breakfast. The wifi ran me a hefty $22 a day. But then, I just wanted to leave Casablanca happy, and I did!

Having had memorable visits to Hyatt properties in various parts of the world, the Hyatt Casablanca was memorable for all the wrong reasons. First impressions can be deceiving - the lobby was spacious and spotlessly clean, but then you don't sleep and showerthere. After an arrival around 9pm the expectations were dashed when the Junior Suite we were given was obviously "tired", smelt less than fresh, and as other contributors have noted, a weird glass bathroom door. After unpacking and settling in, and with the noise from the market across the street and the traffic subsiding, we looked forward to a good nights rest, but that's when we became aware of another noise that would intrude on our sleep for the rest of our night. After investigating where the noise was coming…

I stayed at the Hyatt Regency Casablanca for 3 nights in February 2011. I chose this hotel due to the positive reviews on Tripadvisor and wasn't disappointed. The check-in was fast and efficient and the guy was friendly. My room on the 9th floor was well-sized, beautifully furnished and decorated. It was heading towards Bld. Hassan II, a very busy street in the city centre. As such, the traffic was quite loud, which is also due to the fact, that Moroccons like to use their horn. The window glazing was not that good, so that the traffic could be clearly heard. This is the only critique I would point out. The king-size bed was very comfy and the bedding was clean and nice. Free mineral water was refilled every day. Neither a coffee machine nor a water boiler was on the room. A…

There's only one way to escape the filth and bustle of Casablanca and that's to walk into the Hyatt Regency. This may be the best located hotel in the world- right on the border of the old medina and the "modern" teeming city. One side of the hotel looks over the port and ancient souk, the other the buildings and constantly whirling traffic. Both views are compelling. Do yourself a favor and pay a little extra for the club floor. Breakfast and nibbles all day, drinks in the evening. Nice.
We spent one night in Casa at the Hyatt. The hotel is beautiful and well located in a bustling area. Rooms are very comfortable. Frienfly and helpfull staff. Very good breakfast.

Casablanca is the gateway to Morocco, you only go there because of the airport. The Hyatt is a nice hotel in a good location, it's clean, comfortable and meets the five star standard. We stayed in executive suite and could not fault the room. Breakfast was nice with a good selection of food, the area was a bit small and tables a bit low. We approached the counter in the evening to get a restaurant suggestion from the concierge to find there wasn't one available. Staff were friendly and we would definately recommend this hotel to start off your trip in Morocco.

Casa is not a beautiful city, and most downtown hotels are in crowded, dirty, very auto-polluted areas. The Hyatt is great because it is set back several hundred yards from all of this congestion, making it the best hotel location in the central downtown area. It is very clean and modern, with great rooms (updated, soundproof, great bathroom) and a great pool. If you can afford it, stay there.

column3: sparkling clean, so why did I come away wanting a shower?
column4: I can't complain (much), since I knew what I was getting into booking a "luxury" hotel in a place like Casablanca, but this place really kinda made me sad. It's sparkling clean, the room was perfectly luxurious, and service was always offered with a (tight-lipped, jaw-breaking) smile. The only structural oddity was the bathroom, which was separated from the main room by a glass door (the toilet has its own wood-doored room). This was very inconvenient when we arrived and I wanted to get a shower while my husband wanted to order room service. My dislike was somehow more ephemeral in nature. I don't expect a lot of character from large, chain establishments, especially in areas like Casablanca where some travelers specifically seek chains out in order to escape local "charms." Yet…

funny black and white security guards at the entrance, they really beleive they are FBI agents ! the staff is very friendly. however the bakshish is a must ! the location is very good. it s clean, and you feel safe. but the stay price and meals are exagerated dont even think bringing a friend to the hotel, cause you ll be facing both of you lots of questions, and even be asked to show ID's. causing both of you unnecessary shame !

By Moroccan standards, an excellent hotel.Take a room at the rear, for the quiet (definitely not for the view!). Great location for the Souk, close to popular tourist sites. Don't expect an authentic Moroccan experience, you'll get that in the Medina Souk or in the Corniche restaurants. Don't empty the computerised minibar to fit your own water in unless you want a tasty bill at the end.

column3: Very disappointed with this Hyatt stay
column4: The room was booked in exchange for a free weekend nights promo and if this was the reason for the poor room provided, then shame on the management. Anyway, after check-in I went up to the king room, which was spacious and well appointed but had a musty dank smell about it. I was tired and thought that the smell was probably hotel wide, so decided to make-do and not complain. This was a wrong decision as that night I was kept awake by a regular (every 20 mins or so) buzzing noise from outside the room which went through the entire night. Irritated after a sleepless night, I complained the next morning and was offered a similar replacement room but there was no genuine apology or acknowledgement of the problem. The new room smelled fresh and without the horrible odour of the…

I stayed at Hyatt Regency Casablanca; the hotel is ideally situated in the centre of the city, and steps away from the Old Medina. The decor is sublime kind of European. The check in was good, I was offered a Regency Club access, the staff was very nice and they were always smiling and helpful, also I was welcomed by the duty manager. When I accessed the room which was a twin, I found one bed not made up which was a little bit disappointing, the pad was out and the pillow was in the middle not in the right place, on the other hand, there is not tea and coffee amenities, you need to order from room service, however the room has a great view and was overlooking the Great Hassan II Mosque and the Atlantic Ocean. I accessed the Regency Club for happy hours, the food was good and the…

column3: Great hotel - but a bit sterile
column4: The hotel is very nice, but there is nothing especially Moroccan about it. No Moroccan decorations. Service was great and they did a great job setting up the bar for the World Cup games and the rooms were very comfortable. Spa was just ok - and didn't take credit cards. Food was very overpriced.

This hotel is well located with nice, luxury areas and a very nice swimming pool in the noisy city of Casablanca . The service and the staff was fine and the breakfast was delicious with a big variety of products. Our room was as comfortable as you would expect from a room of a luxury hotel. If you look for a luxury place to stay in Casablanca, then this is certainly a very good choice for you!

Imagine walking into a hotel room with family to discover the bathroom door is made of plain transparent glass?? Or that the WC is in one corner of the room, far removed from the bathroom? Or that breakfast is served in the bar?? Well, that's Hyatt Casablaca for you!

Arrived at about 3pm and was told that the hotel computer was down and would I please wait for a while in the lobby (along with about 5-6 other people). After 30 minutes I enquired about the situation and I was told "no change". After another 15 minutes I was becoming impatient and said so. The excuses given were feeble and there was no manager in attendance. I suggested that they might want to give some drinks to the people who were waiting, which they did. Pity they had to be prompted. I finally got a room and it was fine...for a while. At about 9pm the music started at the Moroccan restaurant below and it went on until about 130am. Having unpacked I was in no mood to change rooms but I was amazed that they would have rooms with so little soundproofing. Having been in the…

column3: Fantastic location, nice design, clean, pofessional staff
column4: Rooms towards the street are pretty noisy - but the crazy traffic is part of the buzz of Casablanca

I stayed at the Hyatt for 5 days with my husband. First impressions of the hotel were excellent as the lobby area was lovely. The bedrooms, though, were very average and nothing like the public areas. The Six PM bar was amazing. We loved the décor and atmosphere and also really enjoyed the meze in the Moroccan themed restaurant (Dar Beida). We had a number of problems with our first room. It was on the 7th floor and offered a fantastic view of the medina and mosque but the rooms above were being refurbished so there was lots of noise. On our second night the key card holder (that turns on the lights etc.) broke and on the third morning the shower overflowed into the bathroom and then onto the carpet in the bedroom. The safe was also temperamental and would often get stuck…

I stayed at this hotel for two weeks and had access to the club and free breakfast at the restaurant which was very good. This is a good safe and clean hotel and the beds are also very cozy. Cons: We used the hotel driver service (not cheep) to the airport and the first time they dropped the person off at the wrong terminal and they had to take the bus to the correct terminal. The second time he tried to drop me off at the same wrong terminal and I let him know that this was not correct. He was so insistent that I was wrong and he was right that he walked in to the terminal to the counter with me only than to confirm that yes it was in fact the wrong terminal. Then he got pissed off and drove me to the correct terminal. Also they put on a speal with coffee juice pastries ect…

The Hyatt Regency is where you MUST stay, IF you can afford it. It is a wonderful hotel. Well located, extremely professional and don't even think of skipping breakfast or having breakfast anywhere else. They upgraded us (wife's 50th), and the suite we had was plush. The only thing wrong with it was that the shower would not drain away the water as it wasn't levelled well but apart from that, we could see nothing amiss and a lot to commend (e.g.free shoe-polish) The Hotel needs to consider FREE internet access to all it's guests - not just the Regency Club (higher floor) guests. After 12 nights in Morocco, this was the only 5 star property we stayed in, doing this rather silly thing - charging guests for internet access. Very short-sighted! The Breakfasts were to die for.…

column3: male with a luxury budget, traveling for business
column4: Looking at kayak site as my first point of reference and seeing how many hotels exist in Casablanca I always wonder how it is possible to see such differences in prices. Finally after my numerous trips to this city, I realized that the most important thing is Service quality which remains a challenge for many hotels in this tourism and economy growing country. Finally I have chosen Hyatt regency Casablanca that meets my international expectation when it comes to a 5 star hotel with excellent service and beautiful design. In deed this hotel clearly shows why it is one of the priciest in the city, nevertheless at least you want feel cheated when checking out of the Hotel.

column3: The best of a bad bunch
column4: Having been to Casablanca about 15 times now, I have stayed in both the Starwood hotels (Sheraton & Royal Mansour) and the Hyatt Regency. As a businessman, the best choice has to be the Hyatt, 4/5 is generous but compared to what else is around. The restaurants are all better than the aforementioned offerings and the rooms more modern and cleaner. The Sheraton is old and dated. The Royal Mansour has a more traditional approach / entrance but the rooms are tired, old, dirty and in need of a makeover, i.e. in one room, I was taking a 50/50 risk using the plug as to whether I'd get electrocuted from all the wires sticking out! This was also the case with the Hyatt but they are in the process of updating all the rooms, which are now much nicer and more modern than before. Prior, the…

column3: Great luxery Hotel with interantion standards!
column4: I decided to leave this comment after my 4th visit to Casablanca and 2nd in Hyatt Regency. My first visit was to the Hotel is back in February this year and the Hotel was flawless. Nevertheless as a luxury product some services were pricy. Upon check out I was explained different options that I had for my next visit. Coming back to Hyatt this November, I decided to take for extra ~80$ the Regency Club room that seamed most fitted for my needs. This room type included the access to Regency Club that offered all those side amenities that we have a habit of taking and ending by paying a lot of money for. As in every 5 star hotel, upon booking I was offered concierge services form which I choused the Limo pick up in a brand new BMW against overly priced taxi rides (300 Dirhams if…

column3: Great hotel, but don't use the Internet
column4: A fantastic hotel with a great bar. But the Internet charges are one of the most expensive I have seen, about 50p per minute or about £35 per day

We arrived from New York to Casablanca and stayed here for 2 nights. This would be the first part of our 2 week tour of Morocco. We were met by the hotels limousine service, it was expensive, but well worth it. We felt like royalty! We were greeted by the receptionists by our name upon check in, Our room was on the 10th floor, it was a good sized room and was spotlessly clean. It did feel like a chain hotel, and could have honestly been anywhere in the world. But after a long flight, it was just what we needed. We ate at the hotel on our first night, the service was faultless, the food good, although small portions, but the price of the food was more than we are used to paying in New York! There is not a great deal to see in Casablanca other than the awesome mosque which is…

column3: Slick 5* hotel, that could have been anywhere...
column4: I stayed in the Hyatt for two nights; left for an overnight trip to Algiers, returning again for a final night before my flight out. I've previously stayed at (but not reviewed) the Royal Mansour just up the street, which although seedy, (has a great bar and excellent breakfast boudin noir - black pudding) I have some affection. I was booked into the Hyatt by my company who felt the security was better. Collected from my flight by a colleague he had to drop me off in the car park; there is absolutely no chance of a non-hotel vehicle getting anywhere close to the hotel's entrance. There must be a dozen security guys and numerous stubby barrier posts that rise up from the pavement preventing access, but once inside the lobby security is unobtrusive, The Hyatt is actually a haven…

We were in Morocco for a family get together and stayed at the Hyatt Regency Hotel for 2 nights. The rooms were spacious even though one of the kids’ rooms was on the second floor and did not have a view, but our room was on the 6th floor, had a great view of the Mosque and the Ocean and connected to our younger children room. The hotel was perfect for the children who spend a lot of time by the pool. I personally enjoyed a massage and a Hamman in the spa. My husband was keen of the Moroccan restaurant that served traditional Moroccan food and had a belly dancer show. Moreover we felt very secure in this hotel that has a lot of security guards to ensure our safety, which was truly appreciable since we were travelling with children from 7 to17 years old.

column3: Great place to stay for a bit of luxury
column4: The hotel is very nice, the room clean and comfortable, about what you'd expect from Hyatt for the price (not cheap). The staff were very helpful and most spoke very good English. We also used some of the facilities and note the following about them: The spa was on the average side - I did have a hammam which was excellent, but my friend has a massage which wasn't great. The pool is fantastic, we spent a wonderful afternoon lazing around drinking cocktails, one of the best poolside bars I've found. The concierge service is very efficient, although there was a mix up with the spa that saw up double booked - no big deal as the hammam replacement was fantastic. The bar is groovy and cool, very chic. The Moroccan restaurant was also nice, although very expensive.

column3: Lovely Oasis in the middle of Casablanca
column4: I travelled for business to the Hyatt, and as a solo female traveller i found the place not only a small piece of luxury but also very accomodating and friendly for a single traveller. The rooms are large and well equiped and the hotel facilities are excellent. The only downside is at it comes at a price compaired with some of the other options in Casablanca.

Stayed for 3 nights in May for a conference. the lobby is nice, reception clerks are smiling and helpful. the room is not very big but has most of the needed amneties. i had food ordered and although simply a sandwich it was fresh and tasty. The main problem is the location, the view is actually that of the poor quarters of CASA and they are many there. You have to walk for about 500 meters to reach the big plaza but all through out is scary neighborhood.

column3: If you come, come for the service, not the rooms
column4: Contrary to previous reviewers mine was not a club level room. While the room is indeed clean it is in need of a refurbish. The windows in my first room didn't close properly, making the room very noisy. I was then offered a room facing the other way (no fuss but no apologies either). This room, like the original one, is a tired room with a desk chair so worn it is almost painful to spend time working here. On the plus side are a very nice coffee shop and lounge bar and very friendly service. The restaurant has a good reputation.

column3: Good mix of business efficiency and charming hospitality
column4: I stayed in Hyatt Regency Casablanca during the last wk of May . Its a shiny glass building , location is very central, in the midst of the financial district. the sea isnt far away and u can see it along with the minaret of the Grand Mosque from the hotelroom window. The rooms were spacious, the bathrooms really clean and with all amenities. The TV had all the international channels which was a nice surprise for me. Internet was tad expensive at 300Dirhams/day but well..it worked well. A couple of minor irritations., the breakfasty at the club lounge wasnt really great ( although it was free) and while checking out i discovered a tel charge wherein I had called but had not connected. When pointed out they were courteous enough not to charge me. Overall it was good value at…

A group of us spent two nights at the Hyatt which for a large chain hotel treated us as if it we a small boutique hotel. The service makes up for the impersonal character of the hotel. Once you pass through the airport style security, which is a bit of a downer, you are received with a friendly warm smile. For some reason we were upgraded to the club floor which was a very nice surprise although we were charged for breakfast one day and not the other. Nevertheless with clean spacious rooms and great service, this is a fabulous chain hotel. Susan and Richard – Westchester.

The hotel where I stayed seemed different than the previous reviews. We stayed in the Hyatt Regency on our first and last nights in Morocco, We were met at the airport at 8am by an A6 Audi. We were offered cold fresh squeezed orange juice and pastry. Yes there was a lot of security, but nothing compared to our exit from Casablanca terminal 1. The security was reassuring. I was greeted by name at the front desk, registered and taken up to the Regency Club for a decent expanded continental breakfast. Our 9th floor city view room met (slightly exceed) my expectations for a Hyatt Regency. The bathroom was great. We liked the glass door and seperate WC. I used wi-fi down the hall in the Regency Club to avoid the hotel room charge. The Regency included a continental breakfast and an…

Everything about the Hyatt is overrated, except perhaps the location. Our room was bizararrely designed. The toilet was separate from the rest of the bathroom, which is nice, but it was so small you had to stand on the toilet to get the door open. The shower/bath was separated from the bedroom by partial glass doors, so steam and noise were not contained and there was no privacy. Service was essentially non-existent. Granted, we were there during Ramadan, but even though we were happy to adapt to the shedule, we kept being told to come back to the restaurant an hour later until someone finally took pity on us and told us that we would not be served (despite a full room of diners eating heartily). Everything at the hotel was gratuitously overpriced. The prices compared…

column3: Didn't meet my expectations of a 5-star Hyatt
column4: I have stayed over a month in this hotel. Positives: - Large room with new furniture - Large LCD screen in room - Clean hotel and rooms - Good and large bathroom - Close to train station Negatives: - Internet is very expensive (40$ a day) - Breakfast buffet not of good money value (33$ and a small selection, same everyday) - Old Gym equipment and of poor quality - Limited number of tv channels (supposedly 27, but most times 24 were working). Should have more channels with variety. Most annoying if you are following international football; no sports premium channels - only free channels - Hotel prohibits bringing food or drinks from outside - In room mini-bar very expensive. Once an item is removed, it is autocharged (can't replace a consumed item, you'll still be charged for…

On arrival (after a 40 minute drive from the airport) I was a little bit perturbed by the number of security guards on duty (I counted eight between the pavement and check in, along with an airport style walk through metal detector) but these are dangerous times and it is better to be safe than sorry. Once inside the hotel the security presence was not at all oppressive. Check in was quick and efficient and my room was spacious and appeared to have been recently refurbished. The satellite channels on the TV were a bit intermittent (I couldn't get CNN at all on the second day of my stay. On the other hand that was no great loss...). The furnishings were modern and new, the air conditioning quiet and efficient (and the window opened, which was nice) and the high speed…

column3: Nicely refurbished room BUT smelly toilet
column4: We stayed here for one night before heading out to Fes the next morning. The room was a decent size; more in line with a typical American-sized hotel room. It had a separate tub and shower in the bathroom. The room was recently refurbished since the carpet still smelled strongly of rubber. We had a nice and very comfortable double bed with luxurious sheets; the perfect bed after a long day of plane travel. The only problem we had was the smelly toilet. Luckily the toilet was a separate room from the shower, tub and sink. Once you closed the door, you can't smell anything at all. We didn't mind the security at the front of the hotel unlike the other reviewers. We thought that they were very professional. Unfortunately it was a necessary evil. The breakfast was a nice buffet…

here are my issues with the hotel: first off, I am a world traveler and have been to too many countries and cities to count but I had issues with this hotel: 1. for the price of the hotel, almost 400 USD, i was expecting a five star hotel. that is what i didn't get. 2. concierge, could not speak english, and i asked for map of casablanca, my response was we are out and that was it. i asked them to recommend several restaurants to eat and had to explain 10 minutes for them to understand. 3. requested a non smoking room, and got a room that smelled like smoke. 4. carpet needs to be changed, disgusting 5. asked for a adapter and response was too busy and ran out 6. got a massage in their so called spa, i don't believe that it could get any more ghetto than that spa. my high…

Great hotel in central location in Casablanca (at the Place des Nations Unies). Very sedate lobby with lots of comfy sofas; also boasts an elegant bar area. Very friendly staff, quick check-in and check-out procedures. Rooms are large, with spacious marble bathrooms including separate toilet. All rooms are fitted with aircon. Breakfast included in all deals, usual breakfast bar choice, pretty much what you expect in a five star hotel. Again, very attentive staff. Didn't get to use the hotel facilities really, but it seems there is a pool, spa and a fitness centre (opened recently?). Many nice coffee bars around the hotel, Casa Port train station is five minutes by taxi; you need to calculate at least 45-60 minutes by taxi to the airport depending on traffic. I stayed there…

I stayed for several nights in a single room. The room was very clean with fresh fruit and snacks upon arrival. No iron, coffee maker or other amenities. There was some noise from the street outside at night and from my neighbor's tv in the very early morning hours- thin windows and walls. The water in the shower had a strange odor. The hotel does not "overlook" the harbor, though it is close by, with the Medina and its many shops directly behind the back door. The lobby and common rooms have no windows and were dark and way too smoky. Some sort of ventilation system is needed! The staff were uniformly pleasant and helpful. Security was (understandably) very tight but we did not encounter any problems. I travelled for business and would probably look for a smaller,…

The Hotel Lobby & common areas were beautiful & our room was very nice but the overall atmosphere of the hotel with their abundance of Security (Men in Black) was a bit much (MIB were everywhere in the hotel). We felt as though we were staying in a prison with them watching our every move. Whenever we left the premises & came back to the Hotel, we felt like we were being interrogated rather than protected by these Men in Black. We hated having to prove to them we were guests of the hotel just to enter the hotel. Our room was quite spacious and had a beautiful Marble Bathroom with huge Shower area and separate bathtub. The bed was extremely comfortable (2 twin mattresses pushed together were not good though and we kept falling in the crack)...The swimming pool and poolside…

I have stayed at other hyatt locations and was sorely disapointed by this entire stay. The room was not what we asked for and was not large enough for the amount of people we booked into the room. The staff was rude and would bother us at odd times. For example the day we were supposed to leave it was 8 am and my mother and i were still in the room. The housekeeper just walked right in!! Then when they noticed we were there still he left, but a few minutes later when we were on the way down to have breakfast, he came up in the hall and started asking us when we thought we would be leaving, and were we still leaving today. It's 8 am we had time before check out why would you bother the guest about this?? At breakfast the attendants were rude and the food was not that good.…

I agree completely with the review from Kuwait, but would like to add. Do not book a manicure or any 'spa' related experience, the Hyatt should be extrememly embarrased about this spa and would be well served to close it down, it it a terrible reflection for Hyatt. Annoying that there is no shop for sundries. We did get coffee in our room. We did NOT get our wake up call for our flight. and the concierge is non existant, I finally found him on our last night and asked him to book a car to the airport 8:30 a.m he agreed but did not book the car. The staff scrambled and found a car on the street, (an older Mercedes limo) which broke down part way to the airport and the driver was great, found another car and we did not lose a mintue. Room fabulous and staff great, lounge great…

column3: Calm oasis in the middle of chaos
column4: Just returned from a one week business trip to Morocco. Stayed at the Casablanca Hyatt for the entire trip. The hotel is across the street from the market. As a young female American travelling alone, I appreciated the security at the front door and the helpfulness of the staff. Yes, the hotel is expensive. Breakfast approx 30 US$. I did not have dinner in the restaurant. Most nights just a drink and a snack in the lobby lounge (aka Living Room) which were reasonably priced. Internet access is also very expensive. Rooms were fairly large, like the typical American hotel room. Ordered breakfast one morning and never received it, but also was not charged for it. A billing problem was easily corrected during check-out. Hotel is an easy three block walk to the main train…

I have just spent a week at the francophone version of Hyatt. Coffee is not available in your room. The Internet works but is crassly expensive at $30+ a day! or $0.80 a minute. The Fitness center is a long walk from the main lift - so a bit embarassing if you feel embarassed to walk through the public rooms in sweaty sports clothes. And there is no shop selling newspapers, in fact english language newspapers are always a day late. The only shops are Louis Vitton and a Cigar shop - not exeactly appropriate for business travellers. So there are plenty of irritations which make you wonder how the hotel gained so many stars. The good news is that the rooms are a decent size and the air-conditioning works (in the rooms but not in the passages). The staff are helpful, they try…

Overall I was very impressed with my stay. I spent 3 nights there on a busines trip. The lobby is very impressive and the staff friendly. They seem very security conscious as there were guards everywhere. I felt secure but not intimidated at all. I ate in the lobby restaurant every day. The food was good but a little pricey if you consider the country you are in. The service was a little slow as they seem to be always busy and not enough waiters. The breakfast was also very impressive. My room was comfortable and clean with a very impressive bathroom. Unfortunately I had a problem as the air conditioning was not working. That same evening I was moved to another room that was fine. It was a bit of an inconvenience but they did send 2 members of staff to help move my clothes. The…
